titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V: Wednesday. Quincy. I had anticipated some difficulty in obtaining a conveyance directly from Dedham to my father’s house; but it happened that the usual daily Stage from Dedham to Boston, has an exception on Wednesday’s, and I engaged it to take us to Quincy; where we arrived at ten this Morning. My Sensations on approaching the paternal mansion, and on Meeting my father, are inexpressible. The world, and life itself, are no longer the same to me that they were while my Mother lived, but here it is that I feel in all its desolateness, the privation of the blessing which her presence always diffused around her. We were all deeply and painfully affected with the change of Scene. In the midst of it, Mr Quincy came; and afterwards Mrs Holbrook, with Dr Harris, a young physician, son of Dr T. M. Harris, of Dorchester. After dinner I rode with my father to his farm at Mount Wollaston, where he has lately lost two Barns by fire, and to which he appears to be determined to remove, the next Spring. In the Evening there were visits from Mr B. Smith of Milton, with G. A. Otis, and from Mr Degrand of Boston.

2. V:Mr Whitney called here this Morning. After Breakfast I rode with my father to Mr Quincy’s, and went with him, all over his farm— Quincy employs the greatest part of his time upon his farm, constantly making experimental improvements, and attempts hitherto ineffectual to render it profitable. My father has employed a large portion of his life in the same attempt, which the barrenness of our soil renders utterly impracticable. A Farm on my dear native rocks, will barely feed with brown bread, milk and salt pork, an ordinary farmer, but to a gentleman and his family, is and always will be, a bill of cost. Quincy who has one of the best farms in the town, and has been these fifteen years improving it, told me that last year he spent 2500 dollars upon it, and received in cash 2300 dollars from it— But then he has vegetables, milk, butter and cheese for the use of his family, which diminish his household expences— This Evening we had visits from Mr Quincy and his family, with Mr J. L. Sullivan, and Mr Poinsett of South-Carolina— Also from Mr and Mrs Barney Smith and Mr G. A. Otis, who were going to pass the Evening at Mr D. Greenleaf’s— I found my three Sons here—it being now vacation time both at the University, and at the Boston, Latin town School. My second son John entered at Cambridge last Friday— George has completed his second year, and now commences Junior Sophister. Charles has been since we returned from England, at the Boston Latin town School, with his brother John and they have been living together at Dr Welsh’s— My brother Thomas, with his wife and six children are also now living with my father, so that with Louisa Smith, Mrs Clarke and her infant we now form a family of nearly twenty persons.

3. VI:My father sent for me this morning to his chamber, and had a long conversation with me, upon his present situation, and his prospects. He is near eighty-four-years of age, and he told me that he felt his constitution both of body and mind was breaking up. That he felt himself falling habitually into low Spirits; that the petty vexations of life, disturbed him more than they ought; and he found not heart and spirit enough within him to shake them off. I endeavoured as well as I could to cheer him, and hope that he will yet long enjoy support from a higher source— He told me the principal dispositions that he had made of his property by his will, and gave me all his manuscript Letter Books and Papers— I was with him till almost Noon— The day was excessively warm, and I bathed with my Sons at Mrs Black’s wharf— After dinner we had visits from Mr and Mrs W. Gray, and from Jos. Hall; and Mr Colman of Hingham. In the Evening I walked with my wife to Mr Quincy’s where we passed a social hour. Francis Gray came out to see us yesterday.

4. V:30. I had some conversation this Morning with my brother on the state of his affairs, and my father’s, and I examined my Sons John and Charles upon their progress in the Greek and Latin Languages with which I was well satisfied— The master of the Latin School in Boston is MrGould, who is a man of great merit, and has given a high reputation to the School— At Noon I bathed with my Sons
at the wharf below. Mrs. Cruft dined with us, and in the afternoon and Evening we had visitors, General Miller, Governor appointed of the Arkansaw Territory; with a Mr Dinsmoor— Mr Marston with a Mr Robert Stevens junr. a Candidate for the Office of Consul at Marseilles, or any where else— Mr Benjn Buzzy and Mr. John Stoughton, the Spanish Consul at Boston— And Mr Cruft— General Miller told me that the reason of his not having yet proceeded to his Government was that he had not the means of paying the expence of the Journey; but that he should set out next week for Washington— I advised him when there to go and see the President at his Seat in Loudoun County, and told him I had no doubt the President would direct that an advance of money on account of his Salary, should be made to him.

5. V: Though I continue in the habit of early rising, my diary continues to run in arrear— The increasing difficulty of writing that I suffer, increases the propensity that I have always been addicted to of procrastination; and in the Library at my father’s house I always find temptations which allure me to waste of time in reading. Great part of this Morning, I passed in conversation with my brother, upon concerns important to us both and to the whole family— Heard Mr Whitney preach this forenoon, and Mr Colman of Hingham after dinner— He came afterwards to my father’s house, and in the Evening the house was filled with visitors— My Uncle Peter B. Adams, Captain Beale, Mr Marston, with Mr Stevens again; Mr Cruft, G. W. Apthorp, T. Greenleaf and several others.

6. V:Mr Cruft took my Son Charles to Boston early this morning. The town School recommencing this day, after the vacation, Charles returns to his studies. I intend however to take him with me to Washington. I took a list of the Manuscript Letter, Account, and Journal Books, which my father has given me, in number thirty-six, which I deposited with some papers, part only of these he gave me, in a large black trunk at the Office. Mr Cruft sent us out a Carriage, and with my wife and my Son John I came to Boston. John went to Dr Welsh’s— We took lodgings at Mrs Burr’s, in the house that was formerly Governor Hancock’s. We went immediately and dined at Mr Joseph Hall’s, with a party chiefly of Gentlemen, Mrs Hall, and Harriet Welsh, being with Mrs. Adams, the only Ladies at table— We spent the Evening, at Mrs Welsh’s, where we met Mr and Mrs S. Parkman, and Mr and Mrs T. Welsh junr.

7. VI:Mrs. Burr, is the wife of Mr Jonathan Burr of Sandwich formerly— I was present at his Ordination as a Minister there on the 18th. of April 1787. I find the account of it in the Journal which I then kept. Mrs. Burr was then a Miss Smith. He married her some years afterwards. He continued Minister of the Church there, until lately, when having fallen into dissensions with his parishioners they mutually agreed to dissolve their connection, and now his wife keeps this boarding house, while he goes about the Country and preaches upon temporary engagements. He is now at Machias, in Maine. Among our fellow-lodgers here are Mr Fitch Hall, and his two daughters; a Mr George Adams and his wife—a Mr Charles F. Adams, Mr BradleyMr Motte a student at Providence University and his Sister, and some others. I called at Degrand’s before breakfast, to postpone an engagement to spend the Evening with him, from to-morrow till Friday; and then I walked with Mr F. Hall to the new dam, which they are erecting to pass from Boston to Brookline, about half way between West-Boston Bridge, and the Neck— It was a project of the late Uriah Cotting the most magnificent building speculator who has ever appeared in Boston, and who has accomplished the greatest works—much more however to the embellishment, than to the prosperity of the town— He died last Spring, leaving this work incomplete, and if ever finished it will be with very great loss to the Undertakers— Immediately after Breakfast, Mr Wait called upon me, with the manuscript copy of the Journals of the Convention, which I examined and collated with him to prepare for publication, till between one and two O’Clock, many visitors in the mean time calling upon me— Mr Waite had been yesterday out to Quincy with Judge Thacher, just before we came into town. Mr Samuel A. Welles had also been there— I found on examination with Wait that there is yet some research to be made, and some further writing to be done, to complete the publication of the Convention Journals. We now made however sufficient preparation for beginning to print them. With my wife, and my Sons John and Charles I went out to Mr
William Gray’s at Cambridge and dined. The party consisted of men, with Mrs Gray and Miss Lucy Osgood a daughter of Dr Osgood of Medford. Dr. Waterhouse, Dr Popkin, Mr Stearns, the professor of Law, and Mr Hedge, and Mr Charles Lowell were there. Dr Waterhouse spoke to me of General Miller, and of his embarrassments and difficulties— We came home, after dark; principally by the illumination of lightening and we spent the Evening at Mr William Foster’s, with a numerous company, chiefly of young persons.

8. V:30. Breakfasted with Degrand, who lodges at a Mr Tuttle’s. He has many things to say to me, and more things to ask than it is in my power to bestow. Called twice at James H. Foster’s, without finding him; at Wait’s where I made some further observations, upon the papers for printing the Convention Journals; and at the United States Branch Bank, where I had a long Conversation with Mr John Parker, one of the Directors, upon the Affairs of the Bank. He, and the Directors here, are for supporting the principles and measures of Mr Cheves the President. I returned to our lodgings between one and two O’Clock; found several visitors there; and a multitude of others had been there in succession all the Morning— I thought of the time, certainly not remote, when we may come to Boston or Quincy, without being troubled by visitors at all. We dined at Mrs Welsh’s, her Son John and daughter Harriet being there— The Doctor, who is the Port Physician remains at this Season almost entirely at Rainsford’s Island. There the patients are sent, when attacked by the malignant fever with which the town is now visited— I spent the afternoon at the Athenaeum, and the Evening at Mr S. Parkman’s with a family party.

9. VI: I find it impossible, not only to carry on my Journal from day to day, but to write any thing at our present lodgings— Our whole existence is hurly-burly— There is indeed little that occurs worth recording— I went this morning immediately after I arose to Mr Crufts, but he was gone out to Quincy; I then went to Mr James H. Foster’s and found him at home. The morning after breakfast was occupied till two O’Clock with visitors, among whom was Mr Jonathan Russell, late Minister in Sweden. He left with me a statement of his account to be settled at the Treasury and his vouchers— We went and dined with Mr Benjamin Buzzy at Jamaica Plains— He has acquired great wealth; and lately employed much of it, in building there a magnificent house, and making great improvements upon his lands there.— Improvements of the ornamental kind, and such as it seems to me I should never make if I possessed the Mines of Mexico— I have seen in France, in Holland, in Germany, in England so many of these ornamental and costly improvements in their stages of decay, that in America, I never see one of them in its blossom, without a melancholy anticipation of the ruin in which it is destined to end. Great Fortune’s may be rendered permanent in a Land of entailments. In a democracy, it is next to impossible they should pass to a second and unheard of to a third generation— Buzzy has built a little palace; but it is of wood— Will it out last his life? and if it does will it out last the life, of his only daughter? Or old as I am shall I see it pass into the hands of other transient favourites of Fortune, or fall into dilapidation and decay?— We had there this day a party of twenty persons among whom were my Father and my brotherJudge Berrien of Georgia, Commodore and Mrs Hull, Mr and Mrs B. Smith of Milton, Mr and Mrs Jonathan Russell, Mr and Mrs Stoughton, Mr Gray, the Minister of the Parish, Mr John Parker, General Sumner, Charles Davis, and his wife Mr Buzzy’s daughter, and others— Mr Gray told me that the Corporation of the University had yesterday chosen Edward T. Channing, professor of Rhetoric and Oratory; and made many remarks, importing disapprobation of the choice, which he said would be peculiarly disagreeable to Mr Boylston— On returning to Boston, Mrs Adams went to Mrs Welsh’s, and I spent the Evening at Mr Benjamin Austin’s, with a party of twenty, of the principal Republicans. We had a supper, and it was past eleven at Night when the party broke up.

10. VI: I called at Mr Cruft’s to enquire of him respecting the State of his Accounts with me. He gave me a general statement of them, and will make them out in form before I return to Washington. Went with my wife, Harriet Welsh, and my Sons John and Charles to Nahant, and spent the day in fishing for perch
from the Rocks. Nahant has been for many years a place of fashionable resort for many of the inhabitants of Boston in the Summer Season; though it is otherwise, almost a solitude— A mere cove projected into the Sea; forming part of the Town of Lynn, between it and which there is a beach covered with water at high tide. There are at Nahant only four or five farm houses, none of them formal Inns, but all serving as such to the occasional visitors from Boston— There is a small Church, used also as a school house, and in which is a small library, collected from the donations of the liberal— There are ledges of rocks, from which the lovers of angling fish for perch, with a depth of three or four fathoms at the lowest tide. We found the Brimmer family at one of them; but they had been there all the morning, and very soon left the place to us. The fish were in such plenty, that we caught at least ten dozen of them in the course of the day— At two O’Clock we dined at the farm house where we had stopped; before dining I bathed with my two boys in the Sea; but the water was so excessively cold that we could not abide it, and after two or three plunges immediately came out. There is a Steam-boat which plies three times a week between Boston and Nahant, and which made a trip there this day— There were also many persons carne in Carriages, some of whom after a short stay proceeded to certain Springs in the town of Lynn— I met my old friend John Phillips who is now President of the Senate of this State, but whose countenance is not towards me as heretofore; and also Henry Tudor. We came home about eight, and I spent the remainder of the Evening at Degrand’s, with a company of between thirty or forty persons, not more than five of whom had been known to me before.

11. V:45. I went upon the long-wharf, to enquire for the paper manufacturer Sanderson, but could not find him— Mr Cruft had referred me there. I called at the Mutual Fire Insurance Company Office, to ascertain the state of my Accounts with it, but none of the Officers of the Company were there. I went to the State Bank; received the dividend’s there due to me, and had some Conversation with the President, Mr Ward concerning the claim which the Bank have upon the Government of the United States— I afterwards went with Dr. Parkman to Charlestown, and saw the manufactories of glass, and of soap, and tallow candles— And in Boston we visited a bake-house, with a new invented and economical oven. Dr Parkman expressed himself much dissatisfied with the choice by the Corporation of the University, of E. T. Channing as Professor of Rhetoric and Oratory—and told me, he proposed writing something to be laid before the overseers, when they meet to act upon the appointment—not expecting to prevent, it, for he had known but one instance in which the Overseers had ever negatived the choice of the Corporation; but because he thought the Overseers ought to know that the choice was not generally satisfactory— Parkman wished me to take some part in this opposition, by writing to the Overseers myself; which I declined; deeming any interference on my part, and under the circumstances in which I stand, improper— His objections are two— One, that of the three brothers Channing, one is already a member of the Corporation, and another Professor of midwifery; and that this new appointment was obtained for the third brother by family intrigues— The other, that Channing who was an undergraduate at Cambridge in 1807. engaged in the rebellion of that time; and although he returned to College and signed the paper of concession which was required for readmission, he immediately afterwards left the College, and never took a degree, until it was gratuitously bestowed upon him at the late Commencement— I dined with my wife at Mr H. G. Otis’s, with a family party, and in the Evening, came out to my father’s house at Quincy. I received this day a number of despatches from Washington, and other Letters.

12. VI:15.Mr Fiske of Cambridge, preached here the whole day for Mr Whitney— I attended upon his discourses, but Mrs Adams was quite unwell, and kept house the whole day. My son George also was this Evening very unwell and fainted. The house as usual was full of visitors; among whom was Judge Davis from Boston; Mr Marston, and his family, Mr D. Greenleaf and others. Forbes, with his brother Ralph were here early.

13. VI. This is the first day that I have been able to devote in any considerable degree to writing, and after preparing a Letter to Chr. Hughes junr. and one to D. Brent, I resumed the Diary which has been running in arrear. My Son John took his brother Charles to Boston, and returned before dinner. I had merely a walk with George to Marsh, the Shoemaker’s. After dinner, Mr and Mrs Colman of Hingham were here, and invited us, and the
Ladies to their house at tea, on Wednesday afternoon next. Mr Charles Harrod, brother of my brother Thomas’swife, and his wife came out from Boston, this afternoon, and returned this Evening. Harrod lives at New-Orleans, and is going there; but leaves his wife to pass the Winter at Haverhill with his father. Mr Marston also spent the Evening here.

14. VI: Made up two Packets of despatches, to send to the Department of State; and assiduously employed in writing great part of the Morning. Mr Quincy and Mr Daniel Greenleaf were here— I had a long conversation with my brother, upon the expected settlement of his account with me. After dinner I took a long walk with my Son George, whose taste for Literature has become a passion, and who is a student of great assiduity— When we came home we found the family at tea, and Mr Degrand here from Boston. He spent the Evening and supped with us.

15. VI:Mr Ward the President, and Mr Shimmin a Director of the State Bank came out to Quincy to have a further Conversation with me, concerning their claim upon the Government of the United States, which appears to be well founded. After hearing what they had to urge in favour of it, I asked them to give me a minute of it, in writing, and promised to recommend their claim to the Consideration of the President and Secretary of the Treasury at Washington— Mr Greenwood the Clergyman, was also here. I went into Boston with my Son John; called at Wait’s printing Office; examined the first proof sheet of the Advertisement which is to precede the Journals of the Convention, and wrote a concluding paragraph to be added to it. I then went and dined at Mr James Prince’s the Marshal of the District, where I met a company of twenty persons; of whom were Judges Story and Davis, Dr Eustis, G. Blake, Commodores Bainbridge and Hull, Mr Crowninshield, B. and J. T. Austin, Messrs. Melville, Little, Gerry, Genl. Dearborn the younger, Coll. Brook and some others. Mrs Prince was the only Lady at table. Eustis proposed to me to go with him to Fort Independence, where his nephew Coll. Abraham Eustis commands, and with him on a fishing party, below the Light House, to-morrow. I was engaged, but said I could go on Friday or Saturday. He thought it would be too late to have the tide for returning in Season at Night; but said he would enquire, and if it were otherwise would let me know to-morrow. Story and Crowninshield urged me to visit Salem, but I declined for want of time. After dinner I called at Dr Welsh’s where I found a Letter from Dr Parkman, reurging the objection to the appointment of E. T. Channing; observing that the meeting of the overseers is to take place to-morrow, and requesting me to communicate the Letter to Mr Quincy, who is a member of the Board. Immediately afterwards I met Dr Parkman, who further pressed the subject upon me, and to whom I promised to deliver to Mr Quincy, his Letter. I then went again to Wait’s, revised the second proof sheet, containing the remainder of the advertisement, and the list of Members of the Convention. He promised to have several other sheets ready next Monday when I propose to be at Boston again— I came out and stopping at Mr Quincy’s house, gave him Dr Parkman’s Letter, which was without signature— He took me into his Library, and conversed freely with me on the subject— He observed that the Letter was anonymous; I told him it came from a graduate of the University, of respectable character, who if the Overseers should think proper to act upon it would, I presumed be willing to be known, at least to him— That I had consented to be merely the bearer of the Letter, without being understood to entertain any opinion on its contents, more than that I thought they were proper to be considered by the Overseers. Quincy said he was entirely of that opinion; and although his personal relations of Friendship with Channing, and his intimacy with his brother the Minister made it peculiarly painful for him to take such a part, yet being called upon to perform it, he should consider it as a duty, from which he would not shrink. He would first go to Cambridge to morrow Morning, there shew the Letter to President Kirkland, and consult with him as to the mode in which the Letter might be laid before the board of Overseers, with due delicacy towards Mr Channing—and I agreed that for the production of the Letter, he should use my name to the extent above described— It was past ten O’Clock in the Evening when we reached my father’s house, and most of the family were in bed.

16. V:30. Had some further conversation with my brother, upon the situation of his Accounts with me. Mr and Mrs Whitneywere here. Morning employed on this Diary. With my wife and Louisa Smith, and my son George, I went this afternoon, to Mr Colman’s at Hingham; where there was a tea-party. Mr and Mrs Quincy, with their son Josiah, and two eldest daughters were there; Mr Andrews Norton, Mr Kimball, the preceptor of the Academy, and Mr Gay, now a member of the Senate of this State— We discussed Heckewelder’s Book upon the Indians— I came home with Quincy in his Chaise; and my wife with Mrs. Quincy in her Carriage. Quincy told me that he had been this Morning to President Kirkland at Cambridge, and afterwards had attended the Meeting of the Overseers, before whom he laid the Letter which I put into his hands last Evening. That President Kirkland, who took a very warm interest in favour of Channing had observed that there were misrepresentations of facts in the statement; particularly in the assertion that Channing had made no atonement or concession, for his sharing in the rebellion. He had returned and signed the paper prescribed by the Government, though he immediately after quitted the University. Judge Story had also taken decidedly the part of Channing, on the principle, that the errors of youth ought not to be remembered to the disadvantage of manhood. And that as to any loss of patronage to the University, which might result from offence taken at the appointment, it ought not to be allowed any weight whatever. After some debate however, a Committee of three persons had been appointed to consider and report upon the whole subject, and the board adjourned to this day fortnight. The Committee, appointed by the President were Quincy, as Chairman, Judge Story, and Dr Harris of Dorchester. Quincy said he should now wish to be furnished with all the facts upon which the Report was to be made— I told him I should propose to the person, who had written the Letter to communicate with him in future, concerning it directly— On returning home, I found that Dr Eustis had been here, with General North, and appointed nine O’Clock to-morrow Morning for me to meet him at Dorchester Point, to go upon the fishing and Chowder party.

17. VI: Immediately after breakfast I took my Son John with me to Dorchester point, where we arrived a few minutes after nine, and where a quarter of an hour after we were joined, by Dr Eustis, with General North and his Son, William; a boat immediately came over, and took us to Fort Independence, where Coll. Abraham Eustis commands. We went into the House, which like the rest of the fort seems to me, to be in the same condition that they were when I saw them last twelve or thirteen years since. We saw Mrs Eustis, and a young Lady, I believe her Sister, who resides there with her. Soon after ten we left the Island, in a small Sloop, and proceeded down, opposite and below the Light-House, and spent the day in catching Cod and Haddock; with a few sea perch. We made a dinner of Chowder and fried fish on board the Sloop; and between four and five O’Clock made sail, and returned to Fort-Independence, which we reached just at Sunset. Coll. Eustis and Lieutenant Welles who had been of the party then left us, and we crossed in the Boat back to Dorchester point, where Dr Eustis’s Carriage was in readiness to receive him, and I found the horse and Chaise I had left there in the Morning. Returning home, I stopped at Mr Quincy’s, expecting to find my wife, and the family there; a party having been invited to meet us; but none of them were there, and Quincy told me they had sent an apology— Mr Colman and Mr Andrews Norton were there, but soon went away. When I came home, I found the family in great distress; my brother having this Morning left the house, in consequence of having given offence to my father. He went away, taking most of his personal effects with him; and without telling his wife or any other person where he was going, but he told my Son George that he should write to me and appoint a place where he would meet me.

18. V:45.My wife, went with our son John to Boston, and they came back to dinner, bringing Charles out with them. I heard nothing from my brother this day. Enquiries were made by my wife in Boston without effect. A note came this Evening from James H. Foster to Louisa Smith informing that he had passed Neponset Bridge, on the way to Boston, yesterday about noon. This Evening I went with my Son George to Mr Quincy’s, and had a conversation of an hour privately with Mr Quincy, on the Circumstances of my brother and his family and of my father. Last winter, after the decease of my Mother, my Father made a Will; which was drawn by Quincy, and of which he was made with me joint Executor; he has been acquainted with all the painful occurrences in the career of my brother which have been for several years approximating to their present Condition; and with him I could consult freely upon what; is in this emergency to be done. He gave it me as his opinion that it was
indispensably necessary to provide that my brother should not return to dwell in my father’s house— He explicitly declared that he thought my father’s life depended upon it; and that it was my duty to make the necessary arrangements to prevent it. He suggested that if some provision could be made with my brothers consent for his going abroad, to sea, either in a public or a private ship, for one or two years, or if I could give him any place, at Washington, or elsewhere, out of my father’s presence, it would be the most desirable thing to be effected. I explained the insuperable objections against giving him any public employment; but declared my readiness to make any disposition in my power to place him where he might be usefully occupied, and remote from my father. As his own consent is the first that must be obtained for carrying into effect any project of this kind, we agreed to suspend further consideration of the subject till I shall have had an opportunity of seeing him— Captain Bainbridge and Mr William Gray, were mentioned as persons to whom it might be proper to apply, if he should consent to go abroad, though difficulties of the most serious kind were anticipated rendering very doubtful the practicability of either plan. Should they be found invincible, I determined to offer him again the use of my house from which he removed last April— While I was absent from home an invitation was received from Dr Ingalls to me, to spend next Friday Evening with him, which my wife answered by accepting for me— Mr Frederick Tudor, and his Sister, Commodore Stewart’s wife, were here this Morning, on a visit, while my wife was gone to Boston. They are the children of the late William Tudor, who was one of my father’s law pupils, for whom he always entertained an affectionate regard— He died last July—

19. VI:30. The agitation of the distressing Circumstances with which I am surrounded; with the deep sense of the duties which devolve upon me, in relation to my father; to my brother; to his family of a wife and six infant children; to my own family, is painful in the extreme. With the earnest desire to do that which is right and prudent, I need guidance from above, which I implore, to avoid any thing which may aggravate the evils that I would remedy. The emergency absorbs my faculties, and leaves me only the despairing thought of my incompetency to meet it. This Morning while I was seeking the aid of my own Meditations, Mr G. A. Otis came to tell me a tale of misery of his own— He has applied for the Consulate of Liverpool, which is not vacant, nor likely soon to be so, and he came to enquire what prospect he had of obtaining that, or any other Office, that will maintain him, his wife and a family of children. He told me that when he came with us from England two years ago, he had a clear property of between 40 and 50,000 dollars, the whole of which has been sunk, by unfortunate commercial speculations— He has assigned all that remained to S. Williams for the benefit of his Creditors, and bitterly complained that his father in Law, Barney Smith, who had taken security, more than sufficient to cover a debt of 22000 dollars due to him, had refused to give up that security, and come in for his proportion with the other creditors. He gave me a full history of his transactions in a former partnership with B. Smith; and in a recent partnership with another person; and said he felt an obligation to disclose confidentially to me all these facts, because if misfortune was a disqualification for Office, he was certainly disqualified. I told him it certainly was not: that on the contrary, I was sure misfortune such as that which he had detailed would be to the President a recommendation. But there was no vacancy nor immediate prospect of vacancy at Liverpool; and if there should be, the applications for the Office would be so numerous, and the recommendations and pretensions in many cases so strong, that it would be impossible for me to foretell upon whom the President’s choice would fall. That the selection from among the Candidates was always made by the President himself, and that whatever my own partialities or preferences might be, I could never know before hand, whether his would concur with them— He thanked me for the candour of this Communication, and left me, as the Meeting-Bell was tolling— We heard Mr White of Dedham, both parts of the day. His Morning discourse was said to be remarkably excellent, but I was unable to controul the wandering of my thoughts, and lost the recollection, even of the text. His afternoon sermon was from Psalm 348. “O taste, and see that the Lord is good” the Subject was the practice, as contrasted with the mere profession of Religion— My wife, Mrs Clark, and Louisa Smith went in the afternoon to the episcopal Church
where they heard a Mr Wolcott. I heard nothing from my brother this day, and concluded that he had changed his purpose of writing to me, and appointing a time and place for meeting me— I found it therefore necessary to think of measures to be taken in consequence of this state of things. Until now my idea had been that he should have undertaken the management of the Mount Wollaston-farm, and thereby have provided for the support of his family— He being now gone the great object recurs of relieving my father from the burthen of that farm— One ninth part of it is already conveyed to me subject to his life Estate in it. He has given me the remainder of it, by his Will— It occurred to me this day to propose to him to give me a deed in fee of it now, and that I should pay him one thousand dollars a year in quarter payments during his life— I asked Quincy to walk home with me after the afternoon service, and consulted him upon it. He approved highly of the plan, and undertook to rent the place for me during my absence, and to watch over its management by the tenant. He accepted indeed this proposal at first, without hesitation or qualification; but afterwards manifested doubts and scruples; asked for time to think of it— Said he would undertake it at least for one year; but finally agreed to take the charge upon him and do his best. Quincy’s temperament is sanguine but his second thoughts make his character indecisive— I had already communicated my plan to my wife, who had also approved it— I finally mentioned it this Evening to my father, who said the first impression of it was very agreeable to him; but that he would sleep upon it, and give me his answer— There were Evening visitors, Mr Artiguenave, just returned from a visit to Canada, Judge Davis, who has left his house in Boston, on account of the yellow fever, prevailing in its neighbourhood, and boards at Mrs Black’s; Captain Beale, Degrand, Ballard, and the Marston family.

20. VI:15. We had intended to pass this week in Boston, and were already under engagements to dine, to-morrow with Mr and Mrs Thorndike, and on Friday with Mr and Mrs Little— But in the state of the family at Quincy and our own it is no time for us to pass in festivities. We determined to send excuses for all our engagements at Companies in Boston, and to spend with my father at Quincy, the remnant of our time, before our return to Washington. I went into Boston this Morning, with my Sons John and Charles, who returned for his last week, at the Boston Town School. I stopped at Mr James H. Foster’s, and then found I had forgotten to take in my pocket the Note that was to be taken up— I called at Mrs Burr’s, settled our Bill there, and informed her that we should not pass the week in Boston. At Wait’s where I was surprized to find they had made no progress in printing the Journals of the Convention since I was there last week. He promised to have two or three sheets of the Journal ready on Wednesday, when I am to go in to Boston again. I asked him to furnish me a statement of the cost to him of printing, paper and binding for the work I have given him; and told him of the effort made at Washington to get from him a part of the printing— He promised me the statement— I called at Dr Parkman’s, without finding him at home— But I met his brother the Clergyman, and afterwards himself, and spoke with both of them of his Letter concerning the Professorship. I urged him to let me give his name to Mr Quincy, which he said he would if after certain particulars which he would explain to me on Wednesday, I should still think it necessary. His brother was still more reluctant that his name should be given than himself. I found at last the paper manufactory-shop, but Haywood the Agent for the concern was not there. I met Dr. Welsh, who had come up from Rainsford’s Island, and was to return there immediately— Met and walked also with Jos. Hall. Called at the Post-Office where there were despatches for me from Washington, and at the Tailor’s, Savile and Phippen. As I came out of Town I called again at James H. Foster’s. He, and my Son John, had both been making enquiries after my brother— He was at Niles’s Livery Stable, on Friday where he put up his horse and Chaise for about an hour, and then proceeded, probably to Medford. Whitcomb told Foster that he had been yesterday to see his old partner Everett, at Billerica, where he now resides. That Everett, on returning from Meeting in the afternoon, told him he had seen my brother there— Billerica, is about fifteen Miles from Haverhill. Niles told Foster that he thought my brother would be found at Haverhill. I returned with John to my father’s house to dinner; and employed the afternoon in writing. My father accepted my proposal concerning the Mount Wollaston farm, and directed me to prepare a deed of conveyance, and a Bond accordingly. He said he would give me the deeds to him, to take from them the description of the boundaries to-morrow Morning.— My brother’s wife this Evening spoke to me concerning him— Her situation is deeply
distressing; left with six Children, and no earthly support but my father. And unfortunately her own character and temper are not suited to the terrible crisis which has befallen her. Much of her Conversation with me, I would wish for her sake to forget— She has been endeavouring to excite the idea, that he should be followed, and found out, and intreated to come back; but her greatest terror is that she should be required to follow him herself. She is quite unwilling to believe that he has gone to Haverhill, which is the residence of her father. But indeed few are the minds capable of enduring such a trial, as that to which she has been brought.

21. VI: On looking over my father’s papers this Morning, for his Deeds, relating to the Mount Wollaston Farm, for the purpose of taking from them the Description of the Boundaries, they were not to be found, and he had no recollection where they were. I sent my son George over to Dedham, to enquire if they were there; and if not, to procure a Copy from the Record in the Registry of Deeds of one of them, and minutes of all the others. He returned in the afternoon, with a copy of the deed from Cotton Tufts junr. and minutes of the rest. I was employed the day and Evening, in retrieving the arrears of Diary which I at length completed, and in drafting the form of a Bond, and the descriptions of the deed of the Mount Wollaston Farm. Towards Evening I strolled over the hills, and visited the Sepulchres of my fathers, and the tomb of my Mother. I remembered what she had for more than half a century been to me, to my father, to her family and to the world— I felt with concentrated force, the present effects and too apparent consequences of her absence, and I implored the divine blessing that the cup of affliction might be administered in Mercy, and that all my duties resulting from the emergency might be faithfully, diligently and discreetly performed. Forbes brought me out from Boston two or three despatches from D. Brent, and G. W. Apthorp, called in the Evening with a Letter from Dr Parkman.

22. VI: I went this Morning into Boston with my Son George, and called first on James H. Foster, who took up the Note from Deacon Morrill and him given me two years ago, and gave me a check on the State Bank for the principal and Interest of it. I called at Wait’s, and examined two or three half sheets which he has prepared of the Convention Journals, and I went twice to the Store of Mr W. Lawrence, to see him concerning a proposed memorial to Congress, relative to certain claims of Citizens of the United States, upon the black King Henry of Hayti, upon which Lawrence and a Mr Hubbard, as a Committee had written that they wished to consult me. They came to me immediately after dinner at Mr James H. Foster’s, where I dined and had a conversation with me of nearly two hours— I told them that the remedial process of the Executive in the case was exhausted; that henceforth, no resort remained short of compulsion, to authorize—which Congress alone were competent. I had told Mr Lawrence as much last Winter at Washington. They concluded that it would be most advisable to present a Memorial to Congress at their next Session, and to send an Agent to Washington, to urge their Interests with suitable energy. I was at Sanderson’s shop, and bespoke a quantity of writing paper, for the use of the Department at Washington; all of American Manufacture. Called at the Tailor’s, at the Post Office, at Dr Parkman’s, who was abroad, and at Dr Welsh’s for George, who was gone. We returned to Quincy in the dusk of Evening, with a South-East Storm of Rain— When I arrived, my wife took me aside, and told me that my brother had come home about an hour before. He was at the Farm house, much fatigued and unwell. He desired not to see me till to-morrow Morning— I informed my father of his return.

23. V:30. After an anxious and almost sleepless Night, I went over at day light to the Office at the Farm-house. My brother had been quite ill in the Night, and was not entirely recovered. I had a long conversation with him after breakfast, the result of which will I hope be an entire and permanent reconciliation between my father, and him. Mr Quincy called here after dinner; he had just returned from Andover, where he went yesterday; the projects which we had discussed on Saturday and Sunday last were necessarily superseded by the present circumstances; but as I was going out with my father, I proposed to Mr Quincy to see him at an early day again for further consultation. I gave him a paper of explanation received from Dr Parkman, and
the pamphlet for which he had asked, and which Parkman had procured. Quincy wavers in his feelings on this subject, according to the sentiments of the last person with whom he has conversed upon it— The opposition will evidently be ineffectual— I went with my father, who shewed me, the boundaries of the Mount Wollaston Farm; after which we went to Mr Edward Miller’s; where he executed the Deed, by which the farm is conveyed to me, in fee-simple; and I executed the Bond, conditioned to pay him one thousand Dollars a year during his life; from and after the first of April next— Both were acknowledged before Mr Miller, who with his Mother Hannah Miller subscribed and witnessed both— on our return home, my brother met us, at the door— I spent the Evening with my father.

24. V:30. My Sons George and John went to Cambridge and entered their names; the Vacation having ended this day. They then had the President, Kirkland’s permission to come back till Monday. Mr R. G. Amory paid us a visit this Morning with his daughter, and invited us to dine with him at Dorchester next Monday. And Mr Samuel A. Welles came to tea this afternoon; and invited me to dine with him in Boston next Wednesday, at four— My father this afternoon cancelled in my presence a Will, which he had made on the 14th. of November last; in which he had bequeathed to me the Mount Wollaston Farm, and other parts of his real Estate— He then made several remarks with regard to his intentions for the distribution of his Estate, in another Will, if he should make one— He also gave me all his papers manuscript and printed, and directed me to make out a deed of gift of them, for him to execute— My wife passed the afternoon at Mr Quincy’s, and I went there in the Evening— Conversing with Quincy, I informed him that my father had cancelled his Will, upon which he urged with great earnestness that he ought immediately to make another.— I took this day a copy, attested by my father of my bond to him; and made a memorandum of certain parcels of land, belonging to other persons, within the general boundary line of the Mount Wollaston Farm. I also began the re-examination of my brother’s accounts with him; for the purpose of a final Settlement with him.

25. V:My father gave me by Deed of 23. April 1804 two pieces of Land, about 17 and 16 Acres known by the names of the Penn’s Hill Orchard, and Atherton’s pasture which form part of my old Quincy Farm. There was lying in common with the Atherton pasture a spot of seventeen Acres which about the year 1770 my father had taken a lease of from Francis Verchild to whom it belonged— Under this lease he held it till the American Revolution came on, when Verchild left the Country and never came back. Rent was paid for some years to Thomas Russell of Boston who had been left as Verchild’s Agent; but who after his death declined receiving it any longer— It was thus held by my father till 1804. and the possession of it was then transferred to me, with Atherton’s pasture— It has been ever since in my possession; but was not included in either of the Deeds which he gave me— I have now asked him to give me a Release and Quit-claim deed of his title to it, which he readily agreed to do. I prepared the Deed, and also a deed of gift of his manuscript, Letter and Account-Books and Papers— The Equinoctial Storm came on afresh this day— It rained most of the forenoon, and prevented me from going into Boston as I had intended— Employed the morning in revising the Accounts of my brother— We rectified some mistakes which had occurred in our former settlement; and I made him an additional allowance; we agreed upon the principles of a new Settlement now; and he is to make out the account balanced. The rain having held up after dinner, I went into Boston alone. Found Charles already in the Quincy Stage, which was at the Stage-house door, ready to start. I called him out and he came home with me. I went to Wait’s— He was gone out of town, and had no more proof sheets of the Convention Journals ready— To Sanderson, and bespoke more paper; of which I took samples. Sanderson himself was there, &
told me that he hoped Congress would do something for the paper-manufacturers— Who were ruined by the competition of Dutch and Italian paper— It was imported at $1:25 per Ream of a quality which could not be manufactured here, for less than three Dollars— At Savile and Phippen, Tailors, I bespoke the materials for Coat of home manufacture, to be sent out to Quincy by the Stage on Monday— Returning home, I called at Quincy’s House. He was absent, and I left a message requesting him to call at my father’s house, tomorrow immediately after the afternoon’s service at Church.

26. V: The Equinoctial storm continued violent all this day. Mr Greenwood of Boston preached— His morning Sermon was from 4. Deuteronomy 9. “Only take heed to thyself, and keep thy soul diligently, lest thou forget the things which thine eyes have seen, and lest they depart from thy heart; all the days of thy life.”—upon Experience. That of the afternoon, was from Psalm. 19.12. “Who can understand his Errors.” both well written, elegant moral Essays, delivered in a cold inanimate manner. The auditory was very small. Mr Greenwood and Judge Davis dined with us at my father’s— Immediately after the afternoon service Mr Quincy came and was with my father alone, about three hours; and at his dictation drew up a Will for him. I was early in the afternoon called over from the Office to Degrand, who came out from Boston, in the midst of the storm. It was so bad that at my father’s invitation he spends the Night here.

27. V:30. My Sons George and John went to Cambridge, where the term at the University now commences. George went to Boston with Degrand, and John in the Stage— As John was going away, my father called him and me into his bed-chamber, and gave him a gold medal and chain, which at the close of his Mission to the Netherlands was presented to him by the then existing States-General— My father told my son John, and directed me to remember and witness that he gave him this, rather than his gold-watch which was a trinket, for the sake of his name; because it was John Adams; and that it should be disposed of for his benefit according to my directions— My father has since we have now been here given away several other small articles; among which are a pair of paste shoe buckles and a gold watch to my wife; a pair of silver shoe-buckles, and a small breast-pin set round with pearls left to him by the late General David Humphreys, to me— At his desire I called early this morning on Judge Davis, Mr Thomas Greenleaf, and George W. Beale, and requested them to come, at eleven O’Clock, and witness the Signature of his Will. They accordingly came, as did Mr Quincy; the Will was signed, attested, and taken in deposit by Mr Quincy— The Quit-claim of Verchild’s Pasture, and the Deed of gift of his Manuscript Books and Papers &c. were executed at the same time— Whitcomb came out from Boston to see me. I went with my wife, and dined with Rufus G. Amory at Roxbury. Mr and Mrs Eustis, Mr and Mrs G. Bethune, Coll. Brook, Mr Hogan, John Gray, F. Ingraham, Henry Codman, a Mr Eckley and others were there, and Amory’s eldest daughter, Catherine. We returned to my father’s house about eight in the Evening.

28. V: The arrangements with my father and my brother have engrossed so much of my time, that I have been compelled to cast away all consideration of public business. The time I had allotted for my visit here is already elapsed, and I have yet much to do— I resumed this morning the supplement to the Convention Journals; and also began a draft of a Will, which it is important that I should make; my own Circumstances having so much changed since the last that I made, that it is no longer proper— I went and dined with Coll. T. H. Perkins, at Brookline— His brothers James and S. G.Judge Story, H. G. Otis, I. P. Davis, W. Sullivan, Jos. Hall, and Mr Hogan were of the party— I lost my way going there, but returned by the way of the Worcester Turnpike. When I came home I found Mrs Black at my father’s— I was this day somewhat unwell.

29. V:30. This morning I proposed to my father to have a copy of his Will made out by Mr Quincy, that he might keep it by him— I also suggested to him the expediency of making a schedule of the particulars
of his personal Estate, to file with the copy of the Will. He assented to have the copy of the Will, but declined to make the schedule— I found this Morning in an old Attorney’s desk, at the Office many loose files of my father’s Manuscript papers in great disorder— I have no time to arrange them; but put them away in one of my new Chests with other papers of my own, to be assorted hereafter— This kept me closely occupied till 3. O‘Clock, when I went into Boston, and dined with Samuel Adams Wells— Drs. Eustis and Waterhouse, B. Austin, Major Gibbs, Mr Shepherd of New-Orleans, and some others were there— Jos. Hall came in after dinner. I called at Mrs Burr’s to inform her that we should come to Boston for the remnant of the week, to-morrow. Went also to Dr. Welsh’s, and Harriet came out with me to Quincy.— I received invitations to attend the Brigade Review to-morrow.

30. V:30. Came to a settlement of Accounts with my brother; who gave me his Notes, and a Mortgage of an Estate at Medford, left him by my Mother, for the balance— His debt to me has become so large, and his Circumstances so reduced, that I have promised after the 12th. of next Month, to suspend the interest, upon a single condition to be performed by himself, for his own benefit, and as long as he performs it. I came in to Boston, with my wife, Harriet Welsh, and my Son Charles— Immediately after alighting at Mrs Burr’s, I went upon the Common, and attended the Review of the third Brigade of the first division of the Militia of the Commonwealth— The commanding Officer of the day was Brigadier General William Sullivan— Governor Brooks was present in full uniform. At 2. O’Clock, a cold collation was served, for the Officers, and company invited, under a marquee, in the centre of the Common— After dinner there was a sham fight; said to be a representation of the battle of Waterloo. There were only five or six Companies in Uniform; and about 2200 men on the field— About Sunset they were drawn up in line. The Officers were all summoned to attend the Governor; and General Sullivan, by his direction made them a short address of approbation, thanks, and orders, for closing the business of the day. I met among the invited company most of the Officers of the United States, civil and military now here— Commodore Rogers had arrived the day before yesterday— Mr de Valnois the Consul of France was there, and I immediately recognized him though more than thirty five years had passed since I last saw him before. I left the field at dusk, with Isaac P. Davis, and went and passed an hour with him at his house— The remainder of the Evening I spent at Mrs S. A. Otis’s, where I found my wife, and a party of Ladies old and young— Among them, Mrs Storer, and Mrs William Smith— There was a Meeting of the Overseers of the University this day, at which the appointment of E. T. Channing as Boylston Professor was confirmed; though with a stronger opposition than I had anticipated. Quincy told me of it; and was much displeased at the Event. Lieutenant Governor Phillips disapproved the choice, but left the Meeting of Overseers to come to the Military Review.
Day. Nothing regular.
